tn.text: Jesus and his disciples have been invited to a wedding. These verse give background information about the setting of the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
Most interpreters read this as on the third day after Jesus called Philip and Nathaniel to follow him. The first day occurs in John 1:35 and the second in John 1:43.

tn.ref: Jesus and his disciples were invited to the wedding
tn.text: This can be stated in an active form. AT: "Someone invited Jesus and his disciples to the wedding" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This refers to Mary. If it is impolite for a son to call his mother "woman" in your language, use another word that is polite, or leave it out.

tn.ref: why do you come to me?
tn.text: This question is asked to provide emphasis. AT: "this has nothing to do with me" or "you should not tell me what to do." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: My time has not yet come
tn.text: The word "time" is a metonym that represents the right occasion for Jesus to show that he is the Messiah by working miracles. AT: "It is not yet the right time for me to perform a mighty act" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"80 to 120 liters." A "metrete" was a measure of about 40 liters of liquid. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bvolume]])
This means "to the very top" or "completely full."
This refers to the person in charge of the food and drink.

tn.ref: but the servants who had drawn the water knew
tn.text: This is background information. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
unable to tell the difference between cheap wine and expensive wine because of drinking too much alcohol
This verse is not part of the main storyline, rather it gives a comment about the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent|Introduction of a New Event]])
This is a place name. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])
Here "glory" refers to the mighty power of Jesus. AT: "showed his power"
This means that they traveled from a higher place to a lower place. Cana is southwest of Capernaum and is at a higher elevation.
The word "brothers" includes both brothers and sisters. All Jesus' brothers and sisters were younger than he was.
Jesus and his disciples go up to Jerusalem to the temple.
This means that they traveled from a lower place to a higher place. Jerusalem is built on a hill.
The next verse makes it clear that these people were in the temple courtyard. That area was intended for worship and not for commerce.

tn.ref: sellers of oxen and sheep and pigeons
tn.text: People were buying animals in the temple courtyard to sacrifice them to God.
Jewish authorities required people who wanted to buy animals for sacrifices to exchange their money for special money from the "money changers."
This word marks an event that happened because of something else that happened first. In this case, Jesus saw the money changers sitting in the temple.

tn.ref: Stop making the house of my Father a marketplace
tn.text: "Stop buying and selling things in my Father's house"
This is a phrase Jesus uses to refer to the temple.
This is an important title that Jesus uses for God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
This can be stated in an active form. AT: "someone had written" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This term refers to the temple, God's house.
The word "consume" points to the metaphor of "fire." Jesus' love for the temple is like a fire that burns within him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This refers to an event that proves something is true.
This refers to Jesus' actions against the money changers in the temple.

tn.ref: Destroy this temple, and in three days I will raise it up
tn.text: Jesus is referring to his own body as the temple that will die and come back to life three days later. Translate this in a way that describes tearing down and rebuilding a building. Jesus is not commanding his disciples to tear down the actual temple building. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This means to "rebuild" or "restore."
Verses 21 and 22 are not part of the main storyline, rather they comment on the story and tell about something that happens later. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_endofstory]])
six years ... three days** - "46 years ... 3 days" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: you will raise it up in three days?
tn.text: This remark appears in the form of a question to show that the Jewish authorities understand that Jesus wants to tear down the temple and build it again in three days. AT: "you cannot possibly rebuild it in three days!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Here "believe" means to accept something or trust that it is true.
This refers back to Jesus' statement in [[:en:bible:notes:jhn:02:17|2:19]].

tn.ref: Now when he was in Jerusalem
tn.text: The word "now" introduces us to a new event in the story.
Here "name" is a metonym that represents the person of Jesus. AT: "believed in him" or "trusted in him" (UDB). (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Miracles can also be called "signs" because they are used as evidence that God is the all-powerful one who has complete authority over the universe.
